{{BLR}}| residence = [[Miami Shores]], USA | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1987|9|27}} | birth_place = Moscow, [[USSR]] (now Russia) | height = {{convert|1.80|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | weight = {{convert|61|kg|lb st|abbr=on}} Â | turnedpro = 2002 | plays = Right-handed (two-handed backhand) Â | careerprizemoney = $449,484 | singlesrecord = 188â154 | singlestitles = 5 ITF, 0 WTA | highestsinglesranking = No. 32 (June 11, 2007) | AustralianOpenresult = 2nd ([[2007 Australian Open - Women's Singles|2007]],([[2008 Australian Open - Women's Singles|2008]])| FrenchOpenresult = 2nd ([[2007 French Open - Women's Singles|2007]]) | Wimbledonresult = 1st ([[2007 Wimbledon Championships - Women's Singles|2007]])| USOpenresult = 1st ([[2006 US Open - Women's Singles|2006]]), ([[2007 US Open - Women's Singles|2007]])| doublesrecord = 14â28 | doublestitles = 0 | highestdoublesranking = No. 336 (Oct 8, 2006) | updated = March 22, 2010 }} '''Olga Alekseyevna Puchkova''' (also '''Poutchkova'''; [[Russian language|Rus:]] ÐÐ»ÑÐ³Ð° ÐÐ»ÐµÐºÑÐµÐµÐ²Ð½Ð° ÐÑÑÐºÐ¾Ð²Ð°) (born September 27, 1987) is a [[Russians|Russian]] professional tennis player and model.[http://www.poutchkova.com/ Olga Poutchkova: Model and Professional Tennis Player], Poutchkova.com Â As a junior she played for Belarus,[http://www.juniortennis.com/ajt/playerinfo.php?player_id=1628 Olga Poutchkova profile], Juniortennis.com and is sometimes listed as Belarusian as a professional.[http://championships.wimbledon.org/en_GB/bios/ws/wtaq509.html 2006 Wimbledon player record], For instance, Wimbledon listed her as Belarusian in 2006 when she played in the qualifiers ==Career== ===Early years=== Olga Poutchkova, coached by her father [[Alex Poutchkov]], was No 1 in the World in the ITF U12 rankings in 1999. Â Olga won the U12 category in the [[Eddie Herr]] in 1999, where she beat [[Shahar Pe'er]] 6â2, 6â2 in the final,[http://www.juniortennis.com/Tournaments/tourna_live_home.php?tid=1286 Eddie Herr 1999], Juniortennis.com and a week later was runner up in the U12 category at the [[Orange Bowl (tennis)|Orange Bowl]], where qualifier [[Tatiana Golovin]] beat her 6â4, 3â6, 6â4.[http://www.juniortennis.com/Tournaments/tourna_live_home.php?tid=1364 Orange Bowl 1999], Juniortennis.com Olga made her debut on the U18 circuit August 13, 2000 at the USTA Junior International Grass Court Championships where she was defeated in the first round.[http://www.itftennis.com/juniors/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100000646&event=1100003977 USTA Junior International Grass Court Championships 2000], [[International Tennis Federation]] Just a week later, at the USTA Junior International Hard Court Championships she secured her first win in a U18 doubles match playing alongside Brazilian [[Caroline Neves]].[http://www.itftennis.com/juniors/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100000658&event=1100004036 USTA Junior International Hard Court Championships 2000], [[International Tennis Federation]] Alongside American [[Nicole Pitts]] she won her first U18 Junior tournament (out of 2 in doubles) in [[Ecuador]], January 2001.[http://www.itftennis.com/juniors/tournaments/tournamentoverview.asp?tournament=1100001786 Nicolas Macchiavello Almeida Cup 2001], [[International Tennis Federation]] She won her only U18 Junior title in singles at the US Junior International Hard Court Championships in 2003, beating [[Jessi Robinson]] 6â2, 6â2 in the final.[http://www.itftennis.com/juniors/tournaments/tournamentoverview.asp?tournament=1100005079 US Junior International Hard Court Championships 2003], [[International Tennis Federation]] ===ITF Circuit=== Poutchkova started her [[International Tennis Federation|ITF]] professional career in March 2002, when she played in four tournaments in Australia, reaching the quarterfinals at [[Warnambool]] and [[Benalla]].[http://photo910.tripod.com/cgi-bin/wta.pl?p1=5117&p2=2002 Olga Poutchkova 2002 results], www.photo-tennisdatabase.com In 2003 she reached the final at [[Miami]] in January and the semifinal at [[Houston]] in June, and won her first professional tournament at [[Baltimore]] in July 2003 when she beat [[Jewel Peterson]] 6â2, 6â4 in the final.[http://photo910.tripod.com/cgi-bin/wta.pl?p1=5117&p2=2003 Olga Poutchkova 2003 results], www.photo-tennisdatabase.com Â She won her second professional title July 11, 2004 in [[College Park, Maryland]].[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentoverview.asp?tournament=1100010033 $25,000 College Park, MD 2004], [[International Tennis Federation]][http://photo910.tripod.com/cgi-bin/wta.pl?p1=5117&p2=2004 Olga Puchkova 2004 results], www.photo-tennisdatabase.com She defeated first seeded [[Maureen Drake]] in the second round and [[Rossana de los RÃ­os]] in the final: 7â5, 4â6, 6â2.[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100010033&event= $25,000 College Park, MD 2004 Results], [[International Tennis Federation]] In [[Pelham, Alabama]] she reached another final, but was defeated 4â6, 6â4 6â0 by [[Slovakia|Slovak]] [[Zuzana ZemenovÃ¡]].[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100010126&event= $25,000 Pelham, AL 2004], [[International Tennis Federation]] She reached her fifth ITF final in August 2005, beating [[StÃ©phanie Dubois]] en route. In the final, [[Ashley Harkleroad]] was too strong as she beat Poutchkova 6â2, 6â1 to claim the [[Washington, D.C.]] title.[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100012084&event= $75,000 Washington, DC 2005], [[International Tennis Federation]] ===2006: Breakthrough Year=== In 2006 she made her [[WTA Tour]] main draw debut in [[Hobart]], Australia as a [[qualifier]]; however she lost in the first round to [[Mara Santangelo]].[http://www.sonyericssonwtatour.com/2/players/playerprofiles/PlayerBio2.asp?PlayerID=310717 Olga Poutchkova (Rus) 2006 in detail] Afterwards she tried to qualify for the [[2006 Australian Open]], but failed. She returned to the ITF tour and reached another final in [[Hammond, Louisiana]] at the end of March. She comfortably won the final, beating [[Andrea HlavÃ¡ÄkovÃ¡]] 6â3, 6â4 to win her third ITF Title.[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100013152&event= $25,000 Hammond, LA 2006], [[International Tennis Federation]] Her first WTA Tour main draw win in [[Birmingham]] followed in June, beating fellow qualifier [[Viktoriya Kutuzova]]. She then lost her second round match against 4th seed fellow Russian [[Elena Likhovtseva]]. Back in the IFF Tour she cruised to the final in [[Felixstowe]]'s grass tournament, where she turned out to be way too strong for Australian [[Trudi Musgrave]] who was beaten by 6â2, 6â1.[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100013977&event= $25,000 Felixstowe 2006], [[International Tennis Federation]] As being second seed in [[Bronx, New York]] she won yet another ITF title. First seed [[Melinda Czink]] was already beaten in the first round by [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Elise TamaÃ«la]]. Poutchkova herself won all her matches and faced [[Belarus]]ian [[Tatiana Poutchek]] final, which was easily won by Poutchkova 6â3, 6â1.[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100013962&event= $50,000 Bronx, New York 2006], [[International Tennis Federation]] After failing to qualify for the Australian Open, Roland Garros and Wimbledon earlier in 2006, she successfully qualified for the [[2006 US Open - Women's Singles|2006 US Open]], beating [[Virginie Pichet]], [[StÃ©phanie Cohen-Aloro]] and [[Ryoko Fuda]].[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100014312&event=1100081658 U.S. Open 2006 qualification], [[International Tennis Federation]] She then faced [[Marion Bartoli]] in the first round and was not able to excel against the 26th seed (6â4, 6â0).[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100014312&event= U.S. Open 2006 main], [[International Tennis Federation]] Poutchkova reached her first WTA Tour final in [[Kolkata]], India, in September 2006, losing to [[Martina Hingis]] (6â0, 6â4), but beating seventh seed [[Nicole Pratt]] en route.[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100014502&event= Kolkata 2006], [[International Tennis Federation]] A week previously she had reached her first Tour singles quarter-final at the Tier III [[Bali]], [[Indonesia]] notching up her first top 20 victory along the way when beating [[Ana IvanoviÄ]].[http://www.itftennis.com/womens/tournaments/tournamentresults.asp?tournament=1100014500&event= Bali 2006], [[International Tennis Federation]] At the end of the season, Olga reached her second WTA Tour final in [[Quebec City]], Canada. She lost to [[Marion Bartoli]] 6â0 6â0, becoming the first woman since 1993 to lose by that scoreline in a Tour final, although she was injured during the final.[http://www.challengebell.com/horaire_resultats/horaire_resultats.asp Challengebell Open results], Challengebell.com ===2007 to present=== Puchkova made her Top 100 debut in 2006, and peaked at a high of World No. 32 on June 17, 2007. Â However, her results soon began to tail off, and she didn't reach another quarterfinal until her last tournament of the 2007 season in [[Quebec City|Bell Challenge]]. Prior to that she failed to win back-to-back matches on the season, although after the Bell Challenge she managed to reach the final of an ITF event in [[Pittsburgh]], losing to [[Ashley Harkleroad]] in three sets. Â By the end of the season, Puchkova's ranking had fallen to 92, and her recordÂ  At the [[2008 Australian Open]], she won her first round match, but lost 6â1, 7â5 to World No. 1 [[Justine Henin]] in the second round. Â Her year would improve slightly as she finished runner-up in the [[Charlottesville]] ITF event falling to [[Alexis King]] ranked 640 in the world. Â She had to attempt to qualify for the [[2008 French Open]] before falling to eventual quarterfinalist [[Carla SuÃ¡rez Navarro]] of Spain in the qualifying playoff round. Â She then fell at the same stage in [[2008 Wimbledon Championships|Wimbledon]] qualifying to [[Eva HrdinovÃ¡]]. Â She failed to qualify for another main draw of a tour-level tournament in 2008, but did receive direct entry into the Bell Challenge before losing in the second round to [[Melanie Oudin]] 6-1, 7-6(3). Â Her last event ended in a first round loss in [[San Diego]], and her ranking dipped to 159. Â She went 15-28 on the season. She fell in the final round of qualifying yet again in the [[2009 Australian Open]], and didn't enter into a WTA tournament until she was given the opportunity to qualify for the Bell Challenge. Â She did manage to qualify, but lost to [[Amra Sadikovic]] in the opening main draw round. Â 19-22 by the end of the season, Puchkova's woes continued and she was ranked 226 in her last tournament of the year in [[Toronto]]. ==Career statistics== ===WTA Tour singles finals: 1 (0-1)=== {|
